newsArray.title: India Look To Extend Incredible Record In Tests vs Sri Lanka At Home
newsArray.description: India vs Sri Lanka: The Indian men's cricket team will be aiming to extend its epic record against Sri Lanka at home in Test match cricket when the countries face off in a two-match series beginning...
newsArray.full_description: Team India and Sri Lanka will battle it out in a two-match Test series starting March 4 in Mohali. The first Test will mark the beginning of newly appointed full-time skipper Rohit Sharma's journey as the leader of the Test side. Virat Kohli, on the other hand, will represent India in the cricketing whites for the 100th time. The home side has a few records to extend as it enters the Test series. One that must be highlighted is India's dominance over the island nation in Tests at home. So far, India have played against Sri Lanka 20 times at home, with the former emerging victorious on 11 occasions while the remaining nine ended in draws. Sri Lanka are yet to defeat India in Tests in India, a run which Rohit will look to continue in the upcoming series. In another interesting statistic, a win for India will help them become the only team to register 21 Test wins against Sri Lanka. The Test series will be seen as a new dawn for Indian cricket under the leadership of Rohit and head coach Rahul Dravid. Promoted After enjoying a relatively easier task of winning the Test series against New Zealand at home as his first assignment, Dravid lost against South Africa away, with Virat as captain. What will be interesting to see is the combination the captain and coach choose to go ahead with. In the absence of Cheteshwar Pujara and Ajinkya Rahane, the young guns could be given a chance to prove their mettle.

newsArray.title: Aussies lucky to play in Pakistan: Cummins
creator: Steve Larkin
newsArray.description: Twenty-four years after Mark Taylor equalled one of the most celebrated feats in Australian sport, Australia is finally back playing Test cricket in Pakistan.
newsArray.full_description: From being rolled on mats to Tubby's triple-treat, Pakistan has polarised Australia's cricketers. But Test captain Pat Cummins says there's only excitement permeating his team ahead of Australia's first Test matches in Pakistan for 24 years. "We feel lucky to come back here after basically a whole generation didn't get the opportunity," Cummins said ahead of the first Test starting Friday in Rawalpindi. Only five Tests have been played in Pakistan since a terrorist attack on Sri Lanka's cricketers in Lahore in 2009. None were played in the decade after the Sri Lankan's team bus was shot at by about a dozen gunmen, injuring six cricketers - six Pakistani policemen and two civilians were killed during the attack. Only last September, New Zealand abandoned a tour just hours before a T20 International in Rawalpindi, citing a security threat. Soon after, England cancelled a scheduled tour. But Cummins and co have stressed they feel safe in a country where Australia first played a Test match in 1956. That landmark match ended in ignominy for Ian Johnson's Australians: a nine-wicket loss on a jute matting pitch in Karachi. After the matting was rolled out, Australia was rolled for 80 all out en route to defeat as a Karachi police superintendent, Fazal Mahmood, took 13 wickets for the game. Australia returned in 1959 and won 2-0 in the three-Test series - the triumph was Australia's last series victory in Pakistan for 39 years. After a drawn sole Test in 1964, Australia only returned in 1980 when 1-0 losers in a three-Test series punctuated by two cricket rarities. After losing the series-opener, captain Greg Chappell summed up his feelings for a flat Faisalabad track in the second Test by bowling all 11 of his team in Pakistan's sole innings - wicketkeeper Rod Marsh sent down 11 wicketless overs and specialist batsmen Bruce Laird and Kim Hughes were among the trundlers. And 1980's drawn third Test was highlighted by a young Allan Border scoring 150 not out and 153 - he remains the only cricketer to score 150 or more in both innings of a Test. Australia returned under Hughes' captaincy in 1982 - Chappell made himself unavailable, along with Dennis Lillee - and were walloped 3-0. Australia lost further series in Pakistan in 1988 and 1994, a tour infamous for bribery. On the night of day four in the first Test in Karachi, Australia's legspinner Shane Warne was visited in his hotel room by Pakistani captain Saleem Malik. Warne, who held the key to the result on the final day when Australia required another seven wickets and Pakistan a further 160 runs, alleged he and fellow spinner Tim May were offered $US200,000 bribes by Malik to try not to take wickets. "I just sort of sat there stunned. And then I go 'f*** you, mate, we're going to beat you'," Warne said in his documentary, Shane. On the final day, Warne had claimed five Pakistan wickets when Inzamam-ul-Haq was joined by No.11 Mushtaq Ahmed with the hosts needing 57 more runs to win. They got them. It took authorities until 2000 to get Malik, when he was banned for life for match-fixing. Four years later, in 1998, captain Mark 'Tubby' Taylor oversaw a first Test victory. Then he batted for two days in Peshawar's second Test before declaring when not out 334 - equalling the then-record of Sir Donald Bradman for Australia's highest individual Test score. Taylor's team drew that match, and the third, to take a 1-0 series win in Australia's most recent Test tour of Pakistan.

newsArray.title: Kohli's 100th Test Will Have Spectators
creator: Sentinel Digital Desk
newsArray.description: Earlier in the day, RP Singhla, the treasurer of the PCA, confirmed that online ticket sales would open on Wednesday
newsArray.content: NEW DELHI: The first Test between India and Sri Lanka, which will be Virat Kohli's landmark 100th match and is scheduled to be played in Mohali from March 4, will have spectators, the BCCI secretary Jay Shah confirmed on Tuesday. The 33-year old Kohli, who made his Test debut against the West Indies at Kingston in 2011, has scored 7962 runs from 99 red-ball matches. During the upcoming Mohali Test, he will become the 12th Indian to play 100 Tests after Sachin Tendulkar (200), Rahul Dravid (163), VVS Laxman (134), Anil Kumble (132), Kapil Dev (131), Sunil Gavaskar (125), Dilip Vengsarkar (116), Sourav Ganguly (113), Ishant Sharma (105), Harbhajan Singh (103), and Virender Sehwag (103). Notably, the Punjab Cricket Association (PCA) had confirmed last week that the 1st Test in Mohali will be played without spectators due to the Covid-19 restrictions. However, the BCCI Secretary said in a statement on Tuesday that cricket fans will be able to witness the historic moment of Kohli playing his 100th Test match. "The first Test between India and Sri Lanka to be played at the Punjab Cricket Stadium in Mohali will not be held behind closed doors. The decision to allow spectators into the ground is one taken by the State Cricketing Associations and in the present circumstances, is based on various factors. I have spoken with the PCA office bearers and they have confirmed that cricket fans will be able to witness the historic moment of Virat Kohli playing his 100th Test match," said Jay Shah in a statement. Shah also said though the recent white-ball series against the West Indies was played behind closed doors, the dip in Covid-19 cases across the country allowed the hosting associations to permit crowds. "While we started off the West Indies Tour of India behind closed doors, the encouraging dip in Covid-19 cases allowed the hosting associations to permit crowds. Based on the advisories by the State Health Authorities fans were able to witness the games in Kolkata and Dharamsala while UPCA had Lucknow T20I without crowds owing to polling a day before the match," he said. "I am really looking forward to Virat Kohli's 100th Test and wish our champion cricketer the very best. This is an occasion for our fans to savour. May he continue to represent the country in many more matches to come," he added. Earlier in the day, RP Singhla, the treasurer of the PCA, confirmed that online ticket sales would open on Wednesday. "We got the communication from the BCCI about allowing fans at 50% capacity for the first Test match between India and Sri Lanka at Mohali starting March 4. So far, we will allow the online sale of tickets from Wednesday onwards as it becomes crowded at the ticket counters at the stadium. Fans will be there to watch Virat Kohli play his 100th Test match and PCA will ensure that all Covid-19 protocols are followed," Singla told the Indian Express. India will play the second and final Test of the series in Bangalore from March 12 where 50 percent of crowds are being permitted. newsArray.title: Victory, apt gift for the gifted
newsArray.description: Deepankar ShardaMohali, March 1As India take on Sri Lanka in the first Test starting Friday, all eyes will be on the charismatic Virat Kohli. The match, to be played at IS Bindra PCA Stadium, will be the 100th Test for the former India skipper. Vice-captain Jasprit Bumrah said that a win would be the perfect gift for Kohli.Spectators allowedMeanwhile, the BCCI on Tuesday said the match will be played with spectators. As per the BCCI directive, only 50 percent spectators will be allowed to watch the match, adhering to Covid-19 protocols. Earlier, the match was to be played behind closed doors, a decision taken in view of the Covid-19 cases in the region. However, The Tribune had carried a report on Monday citing a dip in number of positive cases. The sale of tickets is likely to start on March 2. Tickets will be sold only online."It's another feather in his (Kohli's) cap," said Bumrah. "I just wish him the best and congratulate him for the achievement. If the Indian team wins, then there is no better present than that. But he, as a cricketer, would like to give his best," added the pacer, who had made his Test debut under Kohli's leadership in 2018.Rahul Dravid, Kohli and Jasprit Bumrah during the nets at the IS Bindra PCA cricket stadium in Mohali.Bumrah asserted that playing 100 Test matches for India is a testimony of Kohli's greatness. "It's always a special achievement for a player. It is a testimony to hishard work and dedication. Playing 100 Test matches for the country is a great occasion and he has contributed a lot to the success of the Indian team and will contribute a lot more in the future as well," he said.Kohli will become only the 12th Indian to play 100 Test matches for the nation. Kohli, who made his Test debut against West Indies at Kingston in 2011, has scored 7962 runs in the format. Kohli, who has been training in the city for a couple of days, spent about 40 minutes in the nets on Tuesday.'Ashwin in good shape'Bumrah also hinted at the inclusion of off-spinner Ravichandran Ashwin for the first Test. Ashwin had last played for India in the ODI series against South Africa in January. He has been recovering from an injury. Since last week, he has been training in the nets. "Ashwin is shaping up well. He looked good and did everything in training today ‚Äî batted, bowled and fielded. Hopefully, there won't be any issue," said Bumrah.However, Bumrah did not share the team combination, saying it was too early. "We just had a look at the track and it is too early to say about the team combination. There could be a lot of changes. Right now, we don't have a combination in mind. We had an optional session today, everybody was looking good and everybody was looking in touch, so that is a positive sign for us and we will try to hopefully make out a plan soon," added Bumrah.Assisting captain RohitThe vice-captain said that he will try to assist captain Rohit Sharma in the best way he can. This will be Sharma's first series as India's fulltime Test captain. newsArray.title: Bradford league gets huge windfall due to umpiring stalwart
newsArray.description: THE Bradford Junior Cricket League has received a ¬£25,000 windfall thanks to a legendary umpire who passed away three years ago.
newsArray.full_description: THE Bradford Junior Cricket League has received a ¬£25,000 windfall. The money has come from the estate of former Bradford League umpire and noted Bradford Junior League supporter Derek Shuttleworth, who died aged 89 in January 2019. After a loss of ¬£1,970 that year, the league, which was renamed the Derek Shuttleworth Bradford Junior Cricket League in 2019, were able to show a profit of ¬£25,140 in the year ending October 31, 2020. Bradford Junior League treasurer Phil Radcliffe said: ‚ÄúSoon after Derek had died (in 2018) we knew that there was something in the will as a bequest to the Bradford Junior Cricket League, but at that time we didn‚Äôt know how much the amount was, as it depended on the total value of his estate. ‚ÄúThe money finally came in April 2020. I had an inkling that ¬£25,000 would be the amount but until it was confirmed, that could have gone up or down, so we kept it quiet. ‚ÄúWe announced at the annual meeting two years ago that this money was on its way but we don‚Äôt know how much, but at the annual meeting last month we could publish it in the accounts so that all the clubs could see it.‚Äù Radcliffe added: ‚ÄúThe money is for the benefit of junior cricket in Bradford, so we can put it to what we want, but we need it to support the league, to make the league better. ‚ÄúThe league is financially viable because of it, but we don‚Äôt want to squander Derek‚Äôs money. ‚ÄúIt is too early to say what we will do with it, but we could move to send coaches on courses, invest in clubs, apply for grants, but we need to sit down as an executive committee, who need more members by the way, and see what the options are. ‚ÄúWe will probably open the discussion out to clubs at one of our league meetings so that they have an input, as it is to their benefit as well, but we want something that is of benefit to the league and is sustainable. ‚ÄúOver the years we have probably had a good base of anything up to ¬£10,000 to work with, but that has probably gone down to ¬£4,000 (they made a loss of ¬£128 on the year ending October 31, 2021). ‚ÄúWith this money, which has topped it back up again, we know that the league is financially secure and we know that we don‚Äôt have to look for sponsorship, which is hard to obtain these days, but we can still get sponsorship on top of this. ‚ÄúWithout the money from Derek‚Äôs estate, we would have had to ask the clubs to contribute more to keep us viable. ‚ÄúWe have lost some clubs and gained some clubs, so we have kept the status quo, but in the last two years, there has been very little expenditure and in 2020 we waived all the league fees for clubs.‚Äù Shuttleworth, who was president of the Bradford Premier League Umpires‚Äô Association when he died, began umpiring in 1964 and was the umpires‚Äô chairman from 1968-1997, becoming president at the end of that nearly 30-year tenure. He won the league‚Äôs prestigious Sir Leonard Hutton Trophy in 1998 and later became a life member, and received the ECBACO‚Äôs Lifetime Achiever Award in 2012. He was also given a Yorkshire Cricket Board OSCA for services to umpiring in 2018 ‚Äì the second time he had won that award.

newsArray.full_description: Last week, the US women‚Äôs national football team reached a landmark settlement with their governing body over equal pay, promising the athletes AU$33.2 million ‚Äî mainly in back-pay. As part of the eight-figure settlement, US Soccer pledged to equalise prize money between the men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs national teams across all competitions, including World Cups. A few days earlier, the International Cricket Council confirmed the prize money for the upcoming Women‚Äôs World Cup would be $9 million less than the corresponding men‚Äôs competition. Although cricket has taken its own strides towards gender equity over the past few years, the disparity between male and female athletes remains glaring. The prize pool at next month‚Äôs Women‚Äôs World Cup will be 75 per cent larger than the previous tournament, with $4.8 million up for grabs at the New Zealand-based tournament. However, that sum is a fraction of the total prize money awarded at the corresponding men‚Äôs event, with $13.8 million handed out at the 2019 Men‚Äôs World Cup. ‚ÄúThose sorts of things are really important in terms of the message that it sends more broadly in the community,‚Äù Australian vice-captain Rachael Haynes told news.com.au . ‚ÄúEven just last week, we saw the US soccer team win their fight for pay equity in their sport, so I think there is a lot of groundswell around this, and particularly governing bodies needing to make sure there is gender equity in their sport. ‚ÄúI definitely would suspect over time we would see greater parity in prize pools and pay.‚Äù Earlier this summer, Cricket Australia announced a $1.2 million cash injection to increase the base salary for female athletes that hold a contract in the WBBL and WNCL to more than $65,000. However, this remains considerably lower than the average retainer of $198,000 that men‚Äôs players who compete in all formats at domestic level receive. Australian cricketers are among the country‚Äôs best paid female athletes, but the gender pay gap remains cause for concern. ‚ÄúI think probably the biggest thing for Australian cricket is really getting our domestic players up to the point where they can call themselves full-time,‚Äù Haynes said. ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs the next frontier for domestic cricket and cricket in general in Australia. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs discussions that are happening behind the scenes, and working out how we can bridge those gaps and making sure we achieve gender equity.‚Äù ‚ÄòScar tissues‚Äô from 2017 have healed Australia were touted as favourites heading into the 2017 Women‚Äôs Cricket World Cup, and rightfully so. With the likes of Meg Lanning, Alex Blackwell and Ellyse Perry among their arsenal, the Aussies cruised into the knockouts before Indian batter Harmanpreet Kaur put together a career-defining knock in the must-win semi-final. Kaur brought up her half-century against Australia in 64 deliveries ‚Äî she then struck 120 runs from her following 51 balls at the crease. It was a white-ball masterclass and the Aussies fell 36 runs short in the run chase. England were crowned champions after defeating India in the decider by nine runs. Five years later, Australia is searching for redemption in New Zealand. The 2022 Women‚Äôs Cricket World Cup, postponed 12 months due to the Covid-19, gets underway this week across the Tasman, and Australia are once again the frontrunners to lift the coveted trophy. Haynes, who‚Äôs about to embark on her third World Cup campaign, is adamant the scars of 2017 have well and truly healed. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve sort of moved on from that point as a group,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt was obviously really disappointing at the time. ‚ÄúThe team‚Äôs really different to what it was in 2017 as well. There‚Äôs lots of fresh faces. The scar tissues from that tournament aren‚Äôt really there, because there is just a freshness to the group.‚Äù Australia‚Äôs ODI record since the 2017 World Cup is nothing short of remarkable ‚Äî 31 wins from 33 matches, with just two defeats. The historic purple patch was highlighted by a record-breaking 26-match unbeaten streak from March 2018 to September 2021. The Aussies are also coming off a comprehensive Ashes triumph that included three straight ODI wins over England. But Haynes knows the numbers and records become obsolete when the tournament kicks off. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve played some really good cricket over the last couple of years, but when you get into tournaments it doesn‚Äôt count for much, because you‚Äôve got to keep winning the game that‚Äôs in front of you,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen some really good cricket from all different countries over the last couple of years and England obviously comes in as defending champions too. From our point of view, we‚Äôre chasing them. ‚ÄúHopefully we can be there at the business end.‚Äù From under-12 boys to World Cup glory Like several of her teammates, Haynes‚Äô family introduced her to cricket. Growing up in Melbourne, the left-hander fell in love with the game by honing her craft in the backyard and on the street. ‚ÄúIt was something we always did that brought us together,‚Äù Haynes recalled. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd always find ourselves out in the backyard enjoying a game of cricket together. Sometimes it got a little bit more competitive than it probably needed to be.‚Äù When a neighbour spotted Haynes batting in the street, they invited her to join North Balwyn Cricket Club that summer. ‚ÄúThe rest is history, so to speak,‚Äù she said with a laugh. Haynes started her cricket journey playing for the North Balwyn CC under-12 boys team, and the opposition was at times startled when she waltzed into the middle. ‚ÄúI was one of the only girls playing in the competition at the time,‚Äù she explained. ‚ÄúWhen I used to walk out to bat, it used to take other teams back a little bit, just clarifying if I was a girl. ‚ÄúInitially when I went to those first couple of training sessions I was a little bit worried about whether or not I would be welcomed into the team, and if I‚Äôd have any friends. ‚ÄúBut once I started going to training and playing alongside them, the boys I played with were great, they were very welcoming.‚Äù Haynes progressed through the Victorian pathways program before eventually making her international debut in 2009. She cracked a classy 98 on Test debut against England and in the 13 years since has registered 3264 international runs, 22 fifties, five World Cup titles and four Ashes triumphs. Women‚Äôs Social Smash After leading the Sydney Thunder to its second Women‚Äôs Big Bash League title in 2020, Haynes missed last summer‚Äôs campaign due to border restrictions and quarantine requirements. Haynes and her partner Leah Poulton had recently welcomed their first child Hugo, and the 35-year-old planned to skip the opening WBBL matches while on parental leave. But border closures made it almost impossible for Haynes to join her Thunder teammates for the second half of the T20 tournament. During her extended break from professional cricket, Haynes travelled up to the northern beaches and took part in the Women‚Äôs Social Smash , a Cricket Australia initiative that is designed for women of all ages and abilities. While traditional forms of cricket can be confronting for new participants, the Social Smash focuses purely on engagement and social connection. Each Social Smash game is played with a shorter pitch and boundary; a soft ball is used and no protective gear is required. There are no outs and everyone gets to bat and bowl. It draws on the fundamentals of backyard cricket, where Haynes started her own journey to the Australian national team. ‚ÄúThe thing that really resonated with me was that it really was an extension of the community,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt was just about people having a go and actually enjoying what they were doing. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt about having all the new gear or needing to have a particular uniform or anything like that. You can literally walk off the street and play and not be out of place. ‚ÄúIf cricket can continue to focus on those things and provide different opportunities for people to participate, then we might see the game continue to grow in different ways, rather than just in traditional formats.‚Äù Australia will come up against reigning champion England for its opening fixture of the Women‚Äôs Cricket World Cup, with the first ball scheduled for 12pm AEDT on Saturday. The squad‚Äôs preparations hit a snag on Tuesday when New Zealand all-rounder Sophie Devine plundered an unbeaten 161 off 117 balls to embarrass Australia‚Äôs world-class bowling attack. It was a rare thrashing for the Australians, but Haynes was not concerned by the nine-wicket defeat. ‚ÄúIt was good for our bowling group to be under pressure, so we‚Äôve got some good lessons to take out of today,‚Äù she told reporters at Christchurch‚Äôs Bert Sutcliffe Oval. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a good thing to be put under the pump, particularly in a practice game. Sometimes that‚Äôs really had to contrive at training. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the beauty of practice games.‚Äù Australia‚Äôs Women‚Äôs World Cup fixtures March 5 vs England, Seddon Park, Hamilton, 12pm AEDT March 8 vs Pakistan, Bay Oval, Tauranga, 12pm AEDT March 13 vs New Zealand, Basin Reserve, Wellington, 8am AEDT March 15 vs West Indies, Basin Reserve, Wellington, 8am AEDT March 19 vs India, Eden Park, Auckland, 12pm AEDT More Coverage Aussies‚Äô tour of Pakistan starts on scary note ‚ÄòThe best Test catch ever seen‚Äô goes viral March 22 vs South Africa, Basin Reserve, Wellington, 8am AEDT March 25 vs Bangladesh, Basin Reserve, Wellington, 8am AEDT Australian batter Steve Smith has revealed a worrying repeat of debilitating vertigo symptoms delayed his recovery from concussion. Australia has copped a rare thrashing in its final warm-up match ahead of the Women‚Äôs World Cup, but Meg Lanning‚Äôs side isn‚Äôt concerned. newsArray.full_description: Australian batter Steve Smith has revealed a worrying vertigo incident delayed his recovery from a concussion scare that hindred his preparation for Australia‚Äôs historic cricket tour of Pakistan. Last month, Smith concussed himself while attempting to prevent a boundary during the final over of a T20 match against Sri Lanka at the SCG. The 32-year-old was sidelined for the remainder of the white-ball series but recovered from the head knock in time for Australia‚Äôs flight to Pakistan last week. Watch Australia‚Äôs Tour of Pakistan on Kayo. Every Test, ODI and T20 Live & On-Demand. New to Kayo? Start your free trial now > But speaking to reporters from his Islamabad hotel on Tuesday, Smith detailed how his recovery only progressed after vertigo symptoms were treated by the Epley manoeuvre. However, the Australian No. 4 was free from discomfort and ‚Äúfeeling good‚Äù ahead of his team‚Äôs first training session on Tuesday afternoon. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve had headaches and drowsiness,‚Äù Smith said. ‚ÄúA couple of Fridays ago, I had a vertigo incident where I was struggling for a bit that day. ‚ÄúBut I had the Epley manoeuvre and got the crystals back where they‚Äôre supposed to be in the inner ear ‚Äì it‚Äôs not a very comfortable place to be, I will tell you that. ‚ÄúAfter that, things settled down and progressed really nicely. ‚ÄúI have been able to do all the exercise stuff that I needed to do to get myself back to that ready-to-play state, so everything is going well.‚Äù The right-hander nearly missed Australia‚Äôs ODI series against India in November 2020 due to an extreme bout of vertigo. He was vomiting on the morning of the first match due to the formation of small crystals in his middle ear. Steve Smith of Australia receives attention after hitting his head. Photo by Mark Kolbe/Getty Images Source: Getty Images Smith is no stranger to concussion symptoms ‚Äî he missed the third match of the 2019 Ashes series after England paceman Jofra Archer struck him on the neck during the Lord‚Äôs Test. And then in 2020, Smith was sidelined for most of Australia‚Äôs white-ball series against England after being hit in the head by a throw down from assistant coach Trent Woodhill. Smith only faced spin bowlers and side-arm throwdowns in the MCG practice nets ahead of the squad‚Äôs departure for Pakistan last week, and the former Australian captain needed to survive a pace bowling barrage on Tuesday to prove his fitness ahead of the first Test at Rawalpindi Cricket Stadium. ‚ÄúI have the opportunity to face some fast bowlers today which I am looking forward to,‚Äù Smith explained. ‚ÄúAnd I am looking forward to the next three days of prep before we get started on Friday. ‚ÄúThe head has progressed really well the last few days so I am feeling in a good space. ‚ÄúI have done a lot of stuff where I have got my heart rate up to a good amount and brought it back down and that is part of the protocols of getting back to playing. ‚ÄúAnd I had a couple of good hits in Melbourne before we came away. ‚ÄúBut today is obviously just about ticking off facing fast bowling. newsArray.content: Kevin Pietersen downplaying Temba Bevuma‚Äôs bowling ability barely saved the former from some embarrassment at the commentary box. We have heard a numerous times how the commentators often find themselves at the edge of a slippery slope, where it takes just a few minutes or even an instant when their punditry is proved otherwise by the player in focus. Former England batter and skipper Kevin Pietersen too, had found himself in a similar sort of a situation when he tended to laugh off at the South African batter Temba Bavuma‚Äôs bowling ability. It happened during the first Test match of South Africa‚Äôs tour of Australia in 2016/17 at Perth. The Proteas batters had handed a stiff target of 539 to the Australian batters with Usman Khawaja batting at 84* alongside wicket-keeper batter Peter Nevill, and the scorecard reading 226/4. It was at that point that Proteas skipper Faf du Plessis handed the ball to Temba Bavuma, who was on the verge to bowl his first delivery in International Cricket. Pietersen, who apparently had earlier exclaimed he‚Äôd come out to bat if Bavuma was to bowl, had a quick glance at Bavuma‚Äôs First- Class bowling numbers, which along expected lines did not speak highly of his bowling abilities. ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs have a look at this. Please do not tell me, if you were sitting there on 84*, you‚Äôd be facing reverse swing from Philander, Rabada,‚Äù remarked Pietersen the moment Bavuma came on to bowl. Bavuma nearly strikes first ball Much to everyone‚Äôs amazement at the commentary box, including Pietersen‚Äôs, Bavuma bowled a short delivery which stayed low and struck Khawaja beneath his right pad‚Äôs knee roll in front of the stumps. newsArray.full_description: While Rockingham-Mandurah may not have been able to back up last season‚Äôs finals, coach Craig Simmons believes the Mariners laid ‚Äúexciting‚Äù groundwork for the future. The Mariners wrapped up their season last week with a climatic final-over win over Scarborough that saw them finish the season in 11th with six wins, one draw and eight losses. Although well down on last season‚Äôs second-place finish, the side was able to debut plenty of young players who will play a pivotal role going forward. ‚ÄúAlthough we didn‚Äôt get the wins, it probably ended up a bit of a successful year blooding the young guys,‚Äù Simmons said. ‚ÄúObviously you start out wanting to play finals, but we lost Teague Wyllie for a big chunk of the season and he‚Äôs pretty important to our batting, as he showed on the last weekend with his 100.‚Äù The side registered some of their biggest defeats during Wyllie‚Äôs absence, including a 138-run loss to One-Day champions Subiaco-Floreat, but also pulled off some big wins such as knocking off last year‚Äôs finalists Wanneroo, with almost half the side at times under the age of 18. ‚ÄúWe got to play Jye Donald who is 17, Albert Esterhuysen, who is a 15-year-old who looks outstanding, Mitch Zadow and Mitch Oliver, so we had a group of five or six guys who are 18 and under, and it culminated in five of them playing in the State 18s practice match,‚Äù Simmons said. ‚ÄúHopefully they keep putting in the hard yards and we will see the benefit in the next year or two.‚Äù The Burrage brothers also continued to take strides forward, with Aaron leading the runs chart on 413 at 29.50 on top of making his maiden 1st Grade ton, while Damien made 319 runs at 24.54 to go with his keeping duties. Wyllie also starred despite missing a large chunk of the season while at the U19s World Cup, producing 354 runs at 50.57. However, the biggest story of the campaign came from the bowlers. After finding his feet last season, Adam France led all comers to take 21 wickets at 22.86. Aaron Burrage was also impressive with 18 wickets at 24.94, but the development of Ronan Hogarth caught the eye of those at the club as he grabbed 17 wickets at 21.29 to go with 92 runs with the bat. ‚ÄúRonan Hogarth has been a 2nd Grade player for the majority of the last two years, but he stepped up this season,‚Äù Simmons said. ‚ÄúRonan grew as a cricketer this year and everyone is happy for him after winning the Martin Baird Medal.‚Äù The Mariners may have also found a key piece of their batting puzzle with the return of Wesley Steele during the second half of the season. In just three games, he amassed 124 runs with an average of 41.33. ‚ÄúWes was a bit of a find,‚Äù Simmons said. ‚ÄúHe played 1st Grade for us as a 19-year-old two years ago and then with work, he went back and played local cricket. ‚ÄúHe turned up after Christmas and said his work had changed a bit, and he wanted to come back and give it a crack. ‚ÄúIf he can put in a reasonable pre-season, who knows where he will end up.‚Äù The team‚Äôs progress has even convinced Simmons to keep playing for another year and he said everyone was already looking forward to coming back. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt get the wins we‚Äôd have liked, but there‚Äôs still so many positives and we‚Äôre moving in the right direction,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe had some tough points in the last month or two, but to get some wins at the back end of the year keeps people on a bit of a high and looking forward to next season. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a pretty exciting time for us as a club.‚Äù

newsArray.title: Karthik Sympathises With Wriddhiman, But Says Pant Deserves India XI Spot
newsArray.description: Dinesh Karthik expressed his sympathy for Wriddhiman Saha but also stated that Rishabh Pant has cemented his place in the Indian cricket team's playing XI.
newsArray.full_description: Veteran India wicketkeeper batter Dinesh Karthik on Tuesday said he could understand it would have been a "hard one to swallow" for Wriddhiman Saha when the team management decided to move on from him but said the call was pretty understandable as Rishabh Pant had "pretty much nailed his place in the side." Lauding the wicket-keeping skills of Saha, who was excluded from the Indian Test squad for the upcoming series against Sri Lanka, Karthik said, "But you can see Rishabh Pant has pretty much nailed his place in the team. So then, you can understand which direction the Indian team is going in where they feel that if it's going to be a second keeper role, then they'll look at somebody younger." Karthik was sympathetic towards Saha, saying it was not easy for a cricketer to accept rejection. "I'm pretty sure from wherever I've seen with Wriddhiman's interviews, he understands where this decision is coming from," the Tamil Nadu cricketer said in the ICC Review. "I know no cricketer is going to accept that when you're being told to move on. It is a very hard one because this is what they've been doing day in and day out. "All of us want to represent the country and that is the burning desire for everybody. So when somebody comes in says, 'I think your time is done,' it can be a hard one to swallow. But it is understandable and you have to understand where the selectors, the coach and the captain are coming from," Karthik said. He was all praise for Saha's contributions to Indian cricket. "Kudos to Wriddhiman Saha. I think he has been one of those brilliant, quiet servants of Indian cricket who has done so well over a period of years." "He is still one of the best wicketkeepers in the world, by a distance - I rate him as the best wicketkeeper in the world. He has got great hands, he moves really well... he is a terrific wicketkeeper. And add to the fact, he has a few centuries in international cricket and played some really crucial, important knocks when Team India needed it," Karthik added. But following the emergence of Pant, Karthik said it was understandable why the team management took the decision to move on from Saha. Promoted "Just like MS Dhoni came in all those years ago, we've had a Rishabh Pant who's come in over the last couple of years and has done really well," he said. "When that happens, Saha has obviously become the second wicketkeeper and he has been travelling with the team and playing the odd match here and there." The 37-year old Saha was left out from India's Test squad for the upcoming two-match series against Sri Lanka, with Pant and KS Bharat being chosen for the contests. Saha later revealed he was told by India head coach Rahul Dravid that the team would look to move on from the veteran. Saha has represented India in 40 Tests, scoring 1,353 runs with three centuries and six fifties and effected 104 dismissals.

newsArray.title: Australia's Smith eagerly waiting to play Test cricket on Pakistan soil

newsArray.full_description: Australia batter Steve Smith on Tuesday said he can't wait to play a Test match on Pakistan soil and his long-cherished dream would finally be fulfilled when the visitors turn out in a five-day game here after 24 years. "I have always wanted to play a Test series in Pakistan because it's a challenge and finally we are getting that chance now. It feels good to be part of a historic tour which could see the full return of international cricket in Pakistan," Smith said in a media interaction ahead of the first Test of the three-match series starting in Rawalpindi on March 4. "Many of us have come to Pakistan for the first time so it is an exciting tour for us and we are looking forward to some challenging cricket." Smith, who is the vice-captain of the side, also praised Pat Cummins for leading the team fantastically well in Test cricket. Smith, a former Australia captain, said they are expecting the pitches here to help the spinners. Smith also made it clear that they trusted the security measures put in place for them in Pakistan and he and his teammates felt "incredibly safe" on their first tour of Pakistan in nearly 24 years, a day after it was reported that spinner Ashton Agar's partner received a death threat via social media just days before the start of the first Test. The Pakistan Cricket Board and Cricket Australia later said they had investigated the threat and didn't find it to be creditable. Smith said Pakistan had a good Test side and the people here are passionate about the game and the coming series should produce some competitive cricket. He was also asked about the concussion he sustained while fielding when his head hit the ground hard in a T20 match against Sri Lanka last month at Sydney and Smith said he was feeling okay and in good space. "I think I have progressed well and it's the first session back for me facing fast bowling. I'm recovering from the concussion and I've faced some side-arm and spinners," Smith said.
